subject: linear_algebra
title: Diagonalization: When Possible
contentHtml:
In linear algebra, diagonalization is a powerful technique to simplify matrix computations when possible.

Given a square matrix A, we can find an orthogonal matrix P and a diagonal matrix D such that P⁻¹AP = D. This allows us to compute matrix powers efficiently.
name: Diagonalization" },
intuition: Think of diagonalization as a change of basis that makes the matrix easier to work with. By finding an orthogonal matrix P, we can transform A into a diagonal matrix D, which is often simpler to manipulate.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, diagonalization is used in algorithms like PCA (Principal Component Analysis) and LLE (Local Linear Embedding)
commonMistakes: Don't confuse diagonalization with Jordan normal form; they're related but distinct concepts.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Diagonalization: When Possible
contentHtml:
In linear algebra, diagonalization is a powerful technique to transform matrices into simpler forms. When possible, we can write P⁻¹AP = D, where P is an invertible matrix and D is a diagonal matrix.

This means that computing matrix powers becomes much easier, as we only need to raise the diagonal elements of D to the desired power.
intuition: Think of diagonalization as a way to 'straighten out' a matrix, making it easier to work with. When we can write a matrix in this form, we've gained insight into its underlying structure.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, diagonalization is used in techniques like PCA (Principal Component Analysis) and LLE (Local Linear Embedding)
commonMistakes: Don't assume diagonalization is always possible; it's only applicable when the matrix has distinct eigenvalues.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Diagonalization Theorem
contentHtml: When possible, a matrix A can be diagonalized as P⁻¹AP = D, making it easier to compute matrix powers.

theorem.statement: \[\text{When }A\text{ has distinct eigenvalues, there exists an invertible matrix }P\text{ such that }P^{-1}AP = \text{diag}(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n)\]
theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent and can be used as columns of P.

intuition: Diagonalization is useful when we need to compute matrix powers or exponentials. By diagonalizing A, we can simplify these computations by only considering the diagonal elements.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, diagonalization is used in algorithms like PCA and LLE for dimensionality reduction.

problem.statementHtml: Given a square matrix A, find when possible P⁻¹AP = D, where P is an orthogonal matrix and D is a diagonal matrix.
hints: Check if the matrix has distinct eigenvalues.
If not, try to find similar matrices.
Diagonalization only works for matrices with distinct eigenvalues.
problem.solutionHtml:
Let A be an n x n square matrix. We want to diagonalize it by finding a matrix P such that P⁻¹AP = D, where D is a diagonal matrix.

We know that the eigenvectors of A are the columns of P, and the eigenvalues are the entries on the main diagonal of D.

Since we're looking for distinct eigenvalues, we can assume that the eigenvectors are orthogonal. This means that P is an orthogonal matrix.

commonMistakes: Assuming A has multiple eigenvalues with the same value.

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Diagonalize the matrix A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\] and compute P⁻¹AP.",
hints: Notice that A has a repeated eigenvalue. What does this tell you about diagonalization?
Use the eigenvectors to find P, then check if P⁻¹AP = D
Don't forget to normalize the eigenvectors!
solutionHtml:
Step 1: Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A.

\[\lambda_1 = 4,\ \mathbf{v}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix},\ \lambda_2 = 1,\ \mathbf{v}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -3/4 \end{bmatrix}\]

Step 2: Normalize the eigenvectors.

\[\mathbf{u}_1 = (1/\sqrt{1})\mathbf{v}_1,\ \mathbf{u}_2 = (1/\sqrt{13})\mathbf{v}_2\]

Step 3: Form the diagonal matrix D.

\[D = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]

Step 4: Compute P⁻¹AP.

\[P⁻¹AP = \begin{bmatrix} 1/√13 & 0 \\ 0 & 1/\sqrt{13} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} √13/1 & 0 \\ 0 & √13/4 \end{bmatrix} = D
